title: Sir David Attenborough's new show is carbon neutral - thanks to amazing drones
text:

Sir David Attenborough’s new BBC show Seven Worlds One Planet is set to become carbon neutral thanks to using drones.

Bosses on the landmark natural history programme – which took four years to make – said every effort will made to leave zero impact on the planet by off-setting carbon produced.

This could include measures such as planting trees.

Viewers will see how drones produced stunning sequences while hugely cutting the carbon footprint.

Executive producer Jonny Keeling explained: “Drones made a really big difference.

(Image: Getty Images)

"I mean, we don’t use helicopters as much now, we use a lot of drones, which saves a huge amount of carbon.”

Camera operators were also flown back and forth as little as possible.

“We used local camera people in America, South America, Africa, in every continent except Antarctica because no one lives there.

"But we left equipment in Antarctica over the course of two years so we didn’t have to keep flying it back.”

Keeling added: “We’re really conscious of everything we’re doing. We’re looking at off-setting our carbon footprint.

“We’ll look at all the flights and all the journeys that everyone’s made and the cumulative carbon. We’re looking at how we do that.”

Sir David, 93, said the approach made environmental and financial sense.

(Image: PA)

“Flying people is costly. So any decent organisation would be out of its mind if it didn’t look at the number of flights and say, ‘Is it really essential 15 people come out for that sort of thing?’

Seven Worlds One Planet launches on Sunday, when viewers will get to see the “signature look” created by the drones.

Series producer Scott Alexander says: “I was determined to use them wherever we could. The technology has come on in leaps and bounds.

“They fly for longer, fly further, are quiet and so small, you can put them in a backpack and take them everywhere.

"They give an intimate aerial view - a perspective you wouldn’t normally get.”

Sequences captured by drones include the spiralling techniques of humpback whales, orcas chasing a penguin and polar bears hunting Beluga whales.
description: New BBC show Seven Worlds One Planet took four years to shoot - with the producers trying to ensure as small a carbon footprint as possible
